channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Universal Studios, Six Flags visitors may have to show COVID-19 vaccine proof or test
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Rong-Gong Lin II, Hugo Martín
item.description: Under a new L.A. County health order set to be issued this week, such verification will be necessary for attendees of large theme parks and outdoor "mega events" — those with 10,000-plus attendees — starting Oct. 7.
item.content:encoded: Under a new L.A. County health order set to be issued this week, such verification will be necessary for attendees of large theme parks and outdoor "mega events" — those with 10,000-plus attendees — starting Oct. 7.

media:content.media:description: Universal City, CA - June 15: There were many mask wearers as people packed Universal City Walk, in Universal City, CA, Tuesday, June 15, 2021, as the state of California celebrates the end of pandemic-era restrictions, including mask wearing in most situations. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: It's flu shot time. Here's how and why to get one
item.dc:creator: Jessica Roy
item.description: It's more important than ever to get a flu shot this year. Here's where to get yours.
item.content:encoded: It's more important than ever to get a flu shot this year. Here's where to get yours.

media:content.media:description: SAN FERNANDO , CA - OCTOBER 16: Licensed Vocational Nurse Theresa Jackson, left, gives a flu shot to Los Angeles Unified School District Superintendent Austin Beutner, right, at San Fernando Middle School. L.A. Unified is offering free flu shots to students and their families through Health Net to forestall a twindemic of COVID-19 combined with flu season on Friday, Oct. 16, 2020 in San Fernando , CA. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Declining child coronavirus cases indicate generally safe school reopenings in L.A. County
item.dc:creator: Melissa Gomez, Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money
item.description: The low rates will allow school district to adopt relaxed quarantine policies so students can stay in class.
item.content:encoded: The low rates will allow school district to adopt relaxed quarantine policies so students can stay in class.

media:content.media:description: ARCADIA-CA-SEPTEMER 10, 2021: Lucas Sun, left, and Vito Hsu, both 13, listen as their teacher Karalee Nakatsuka instructs a history lesson about 9/11 at First Avenue Middle School in Arcadia on Friday, September 10, 2021. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. City Council President Nury Martinez won't run for mayor in 2022
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser
item.description: Other potential candidates — U.S. Rep. Karen Bass, Councilman Kevin de León and real estate developer Rick Caruso — still haven't announced their plans.
item.content:encoded: Other potential candidates — U.S. Rep. Karen Bass, Councilman Kevin de León and real estate developer Rick Caruso — still haven't announced their plans.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JANUARY 14, 2020 Los Angeles City Council 6th district representative Nury Martinez addresses the crowded city council chambers Tuesday for the first time as President of the City Council. A daughter of Mexican immigrants she becomes the first Latina to presided over Los Angeles City Council meetings as President chosen unanimously by the City Council last December. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A water scooter, an AR-15 rifle and a bag of heroin: Two arrested at Napa County lake
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Deputies uncovered the contraband while responding to a suspicious vehicle call at Lake Berryessa.
item.content:encoded: Deputies uncovered the contraband while responding to a suspicious vehicle call at Lake Berryessa.

media:content.media:description: The Napa County Sheriff's found approximately 3 ounces of heroin, an AR-15 rifle and more than $8,500 in cash during a routine call to Lake Berryessa.

item.title: Arnold Schwarzenegger says voters were right to retain Newsom, calls GOP field 'disastrous'
item.dc:creator: Seema Mehta
item.description: Republican Arnold Schwarzenegger, who won office through a recall, says he's glad Newsom wasn't ousted
item.content:encoded: Republican Arnold Schwarzenegger, who won office through a recall, says he's glad Newsom wasn't ousted

media:content.media:description: Arnold Schwarzenegger talks about Digital Sustainability during the Digital X conference in Cologne, Germany, Tuesday, Sept. 7, 2021. (Roberto Pfeil/dpa via AP)

item.title: L.A. County sheriff has legal power to ban gang-like groups of deputies, county lawyers say
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva has broad legal authority to crack down on entrenched, gang-like groups of deputies, according to attorneys for the county.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva has broad legal authority to crack down on entrenched, gang-like groups of deputies, according to attorneys for the county.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 26: Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva discusses organizational change, transparency, accountability and how they relate to the issue of deputy cliques during a press conference at the Hall of Justice Wednesday May 26, 2021. The Sheriff also addressed a damages claim filed by the city of Compton against Los Angeles County today, alleging the sheriff's department has bilked the city out of millions of dollars by falsely reporting the amount of time deputies spend patrolling the city. Sheriff Alex Villanueva dismissed the allegations. "We have about 45 contracts and we measure the minutes, and there's a rate -- we have to get close to 100%, either slightly above or slightly below,'' Villanueva said. "If we're missing that target, I don't think it's going to be the grand conspiracy that the outgoing mayor of Compton wants it to be. "But we'll definitely take the allegation seriously, and we are already doing a thorough audit on it, and we'll take action based on the results of that. Nothing unusual there. But to call it a fraud, that might be a little bit of a stretch.'' Hall of Justice on Wednesday, May 26, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times).

item.title: California risks forfeiting millions meant for struggling renters, auditor warns
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Auditor Elaine Howle says delays in the rent relief program and uncertainty over federal rules raise concern that California won't distribute $1.8 billion by Sept. 30.
item.content:encoded: Auditor Elaine Howle says delays in the rent relief program and uncertainty over federal rules raise concern that California won't distribute $1.8 billion by Sept. 30.

media:content.media:description: EL MONTE, CA - MARCH 29: Tenant rights activists assemble at the El Monte City Hall to demand that the El Monte City Council pass an eviction moratorium barring all evictions during the coronavirus pandemic on Sunday, March 29, 2020 in El Monte, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Giant Forest trees prepped for flames in Sequoia National Park as KNP Complex fire closes in
item.dc:creator: Lila Seidman
item.description: Flames from the KNP Complex fire could soon reach the sequoias in the Giant Forest, fire crews warn.
item.content:encoded: Flames from the KNP Complex fire could soon reach the sequoias in the Giant Forest, fire crews warn.

media:content.media:description: SEQUOIA NATIONAL PARK, CA - September 15,2021: Flames burn through brush on a hillside near the entrance station to Sequoia National Park near Three Rivers as the KNP Complex fire threatens the area on Wednesday, Sept. 15, 2021 in Sequoia National Park, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Effort to recall L.A. County D.A. George Gascón fizzles out, but a retry is coming
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Committee seeking to recall L.A. County Dist. Atty. George Gascón says it won't meet October petition deadline, but will try again later this year.
item.content:encoded: Committee seeking to recall L.A. County Dist. Atty. George Gascón says it won't meet October petition deadline, but will try again later this year.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 26: Desiree Andrade, left, whose son Julien Andrade was murdered in 2018 is joined by other crime victims as the signature gathering effort to recall L.A. County D.A. George Gascon held its introductory press conference on Wednesday morning in front of the Hall of Justice in downtown LA. LA County Sheriff Alex Villanueva, former LA County District Attorney Steve Cooley and former LA City Councilman Dennis Zine were there in support. Hall of Justice on Wednesday, May 26, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times).

item.title: Off-duty L.A. County Sheriff's deputy is killed, passenger injured in high-speed crash
item.dc:creator: Melissa Hernandez
item.description: The off-duty sheriff's deputy died after he drove a vintage sports car into a light pole in Temple City and was ejected from the vehicle, according to the California Highway Patrol.
item.content:encoded: The off-duty sheriff's deputy died after he drove a vintage sports car into a light pole in Temple City and was ejected from the vehicle, according to the California Highway Patrol.

item.title: California Supreme Court Justice Mariano-Florentino Cuéllar stepping down to head think tank
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Cuéllar, the only Latino on the state's top court, will step down to head an influential foreign policy organization.
item.content:encoded: Cuéllar, the only Latino on the state's top court, will step down to head an influential foreign policy organization.

media:content.media:description: FILE - Mariano-Florentino Cuellar, left, is sworn in as an associate justice to the California Supreme Court by Gov. Jerry Brown during an inauguration ceremony in Sacramento, Calif., Monday, Jan. 5, 2015. The California Supreme Court ruled Thursday, March 25, 2021 that judges must consider suspects' ability to pay when they set bail, essentially requiring that indigent defendants be freed unless they are deemed too dangerous to be released awaiting trial. Cuellar wrote on behalf of the court — conditions that "in many cases protect public and victim safety as well as assure the arrestee's appearance at trial." (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, file)

item.title: Snow in Death Valley, the hottest place on Earth? It's not what it looks like
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Park officials said the photo of salty white hills was snapped about a mile north of Furnace Creek, an area known for its extreme heat.
item.content:encoded: Park officials said the photo of salty white hills was snapped about a mile north of Furnace Creek, an area known for its extreme heat.

media:content.media:description: Photo of a snow-like dusting at Death Valley National Park that was caused by rain soaking into the soil and dissolving salt beneath the surface, rangers said.

item.title: L.A. County sees big drops in coronavirus cases, hospitalizations
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: About a month ago, L.A. County was averaging more than 3,400 new coronavirus infections a day. As of Tuesday, it was averaging fewer than 1,800 a day.
item.content:encoded: About a month ago, L.A. County was averaging more than 3,400 new coronavirus infections a day. As of Tuesday, it was averaging fewer than 1,800 a day.

media:content.media:description: SOUTH LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 15, 2021 - - Shauni Edmund, 13, left, and Ty'lir Langston, 11, hug during a mindfulness exercise before learning practical skills in technology at a tech summer camp at SoLA Impact's new Tech and Entrepreneurship CenterThe Beehive in South Los Angeles on July 15, 2021. Children learn animation, digital storytelling, video game design, Photoshop, coding and website design at the tech summer camp. The tech summer camp has been held over the last month, impacting about 100 local youth. Mayor Eric Garcetti visited The Beehive with other dignitaries and philanthropists. The event aims to highlight the practical ways that private, public and institutional capital can positively impact minority communities in South and East Los Angeles. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 1 in 3 COVID-19 patients suffer from long COVID, a CDC study of Long Beach residents finds
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money
item.description: These long COVID patients reported at least one symptom of COVID-19 two months after first testing positive for the coronavirus, the CDC study says.
item.content:encoded: These long COVID patients reported at least one symptom of COVID-19 two months after first testing positive for the coronavirus, the CDC study says.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - JULY 06: The city of Long Beach's Department of Health & Human Services holds an evening COVID-19 vaccination clinic Long Beach City College Pacific Coast Campus. on Tuesday, July 6, 2021 in Long Beach, CA. Doses of the Pfizer, Moderna and Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccines are available. The site is open Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. to 8 p.m. until otherwise announced. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: You will have to show vaccine proof at L.A. nightclubs and bars. How it will work

item.description: The L.A. County mandate will require patrons and employees to have at least one vaccine dose by Oct. 7 and be fully vaccinated by Nov. 4.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. County mandate will require patrons and employees to have at least one vaccine dose by Oct. 7 and be fully vaccinated by Nov. 4.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 30: Customers show proof of vaccination inside Permanent Records Roadhouse on Friday, July 30, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. (Mariah Tauger / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California recall price tag could hit $300 million. Some say it was a waste of money
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom survived the recall attempt by a big margin, and that has led some to question whether the system works and if changes are needed.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom survived the recall attempt by a big margin, and that has led some to question whether the system works and if changes are needed.

media:content.media:description: Costa Mesa, CA, Tuesday, September 14, 2021 - Kellie Avakian crosses her fingers but shows disappointment as poll results are broadcast showing a nearly 70 percent vote against the recall of Governor Newsom at a rally for candidate Larry Elder at the Orange County Hilton. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Man shot and killed at Metro station in downtown L.A.
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: The man was shot as he exited a train at the Blue Line's Washington Station, and authorities have not found the shooter.
item.content:encoded: The man was shot as he exited a train at the Blue Line's Washington Station, and authorities have not found the shooter.

media:content.media:description: An investigation is underway after a man was shot to death outside a Metro Blue Line train Wednesday night.

item.title: World's largest trees under siege from California wildfire as sequoias face new perils
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith, Lila Seidman
item.description: The 8,940-acre KNP Complex fire is within striking distance of Sequoia National Park's Giant Forest, home to the largest tree on Earth, officials said.
item.content:encoded: The 8,940-acre KNP Complex fire is within striking distance of Sequoia National Park's Giant Forest, home to the largest tree on Earth, officials said.

media:content.media:description: A firefighter lays hose around the Foothills Visitor Center while battling the KNP Complex Fire in Sequoia National Park, Calif., on Tuesday, Sept. 14, 2021. The blaze is burning near the Giant Forest, home to more than 2,000 giant sequoias. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: After Newsom's recall triumph, Republicans need to do the math: Stop wasting time and money
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Columnist George Skelton writes that Newsom's landslide victory proved what most already knew: No Trump-supporting conservative can win statewide office in liberal-leaning California.
item.content:encoded: Columnist George Skelton writes that Newsom's landslide victory proved what most already knew: No Trump-supporting conservative can win statewide office in liberal-leaning California.

media:content.media:description: Costa Mesa, CA, Tuesday, September 14, 2021 - Governor recall candidate Larry Elder rallies supporters at the Orange County Hilton. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County takes first steps to end urban oil drilling
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: The L.A. County Board of Supervisors unanimously voted to ban new oil wells and evaluate the status of existing ones while changing their zoning to "nonconforming."
item.content:encoded: The L.A. County Board of Supervisors unanimously voted to ban new oil wells and evaluate the status of existing ones while changing their zoning to "nonconforming."

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 18, 2021, file photo, apartment buildings rise behind pump jacks operating at the Inglewood Oil Field in Los Angeles. California state oil regulators missed a spring deadline for new regulations designed to protect health and safety near oil and gas drillings sites. Environmental advocates have been pressuring Gov. Gavin Newsom's administration to adopt mandatory distances between wells and sites like schools and homes. (AP Photo/Jae C. Hong, File)

item.title: School mural is transformed after original offended some Korean Americans
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: Sun rays that some said reminded them of Japanese battle flag are muted and partially obscured.
item.content:encoded: Sun rays that some said reminded them of Japanese battle flag are muted and partially obscured.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - September 15,2021: LAUSD officials and community members cheer as an updated version of the Ava Gardner Mural at the Robert F. Kennedy Community Schools is unveiled on Wednesday, Sept. 15, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. The update of the mural, created by artist Beau Stanton, had been delayed by over two years due to the COVID-19 pandemic. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: A California in crisis awaits Newsom after landslide win in recall

item.title: L.A. fire captain severely burned in downtown explosion sues building owners, vape shops

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-MAY 18, 2020. Members of the Los Angeles Fire Department investigate the scene of a fiery explosion on Boyd St. in the downtown los Angeles Toy District that injured 12 firefighters and damaged buildings and fire equipment, authorities said. The explosion happened around 6:30 pm Saturday, when firefighters responded to the initial call of a fire in the single-story building at 327 Boyd St., between Third and Fourth Streets. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times

item.title: How many ballots are left to be counted in the California recall election?
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: More than 9 million recall ballots have been counted out of an estimated 13 million cast — enough for Gov. Gavin Newsom to declare victory.
item.content:encoded: More than 9 million recall ballots have been counted out of an estimated 13 million cast — enough for Gov. Gavin Newsom to declare victory.

media:content.media:description: Pomona , CA - September 15: Election worker Yolanda Lavayen unbag ballots for the Sept. 14, recall election at the Los Angeles County Registrar of Voters satellite office at Fairplex on Wednesday, Sept. 15, 2021 in Pomona , CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's costly, confusing recall sparks an effort to rethink the rules
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: California lawmakers agreed to spend at least $276 million in the most recent state budget to cover the costs of the recall, but some elections officials have estimated the final tab will be closer to $300 million.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers agreed to spend at least $276 million in the most recent state budget to cover the costs of the recall, but some elections officials have estimated the final tab will be closer to $300 million.

Gavin Newsom is seen as guests arrive for an election party at the Pineapple Hill Saloon & Grill in Los Angeles on Tuesday, Sept. 14, 2021. A small group of pro-recall voters gathered at the bar and eatery to watch the results come in. (AP Photo/Richard Vogel)

item.title: L.A. County plans to require proof of vaccination at indoor bars, nightclubs, breweries, wineries
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Rong-Gong Lin II, Stephanie Breijo
item.description: A new health order will require proof of COVID-19 vaccination to enter indoor bars, wineries, breweries, nightclubs and lounges in Los Angeles County.
item.content:encoded: A new health order will require proof of COVID-19 vaccination to enter indoor bars, wineries, breweries, nightclubs and lounges in Los Angeles County.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 10: Bennett Erickson, left, general manager at Sunset Beer checks proof of vaccination for Anthony Trapanese, middle, and Caitlin Forst, right, on Tuesday, Aug. 10, 2021 in the Echo Park neighborhood of Los Angeles, CA. Los Angeles County required to show proof of vaccination before entering. The report will consider whether a mandate should require one dose or full vaccination to enter certain locations, and whether the policy should apply to all indoor public spaces or certain nonessential businesses and events. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California recall election results closely linked to COVID-19 vaccination rates
item.dc:creator: Matt Stiles
item.description: Higher vaccination rates correlated with higher support for Gov. Newsom in the recall election, and vice versa, analysis of voting data shows.
item.content:encoded: Higher vaccination rates correlated with higher support for Gov. Newsom in the recall election, and vice versa, analysis of voting data shows.

media:content.media:description: Universal City, CA - June 15: As part of California's full reopening, marking the end of pandemic-era restrictions like masks, social distancing and most capacity restrictions, Gov. Gavin Newsom juggles numbered balls following the conclusion of a press conference at Universal Studios, in Universal City, CA, Tuesday, June 15, 2021. Governor Newsom drew 10 winners to receive $1.5 million each, for a total of $15 million, as part of the final cash prize drawing in the state's $116.5 million Vax for the Win program - the largest vaccine incentive program in the nation. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Vaccines and Trump: Will Newsom's formula for beating the recall work for Democrats in 2022?
item.dc:creator: Melanie Mason, Janet Hook
item.description: Newsom won by stoking fears of the GOP to turn out his base, and by touting his handling of the pandemic. Would the strategy work outside California?
item.content:encoded: Newsom won by stoking fears of the GOP to turn out his base, and by touting his handling of the pandemic. Would the strategy work outside California?

media:content.media:description: Long Beach, CA - September 13: U.S. US President Joe Biden (L) waves onstage with California Governor Gavin Newsom and his wife Jennifer Siebel Newsom during a campaign event at Long Beach City Collage, on Monday, Sept. 13, 2021 in Long Beach, CA. (Wally Skalij / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: French Laundry. Pandemic. Trump. Chaos. All played big as voters cast recall ballots
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives, Priscella Vega, Melissa Gomez, Joe Mozingo
item.description: On Tuesday, the California voters most active leaned toward recalling Newsom, but that was just part of the overall picture.
item.content:encoded: On Tuesday, the California voters most active leaned toward recalling Newsom, but that was just part of the overall picture.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom responds to a question while meeting with reporters after casting his recall ballot at a voting center in Sacramento, Calif., Friday, Sept. 10, 2021. The last day to vote in the recall election is Tuesday Sept. 14. A majority of voters must mark "no" on the recall to keep Newsom in office. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Newsom thanks California for 'rejecting the division, rejecting the cynicism'
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The governor said he saw the recall's failure as a hopeful sign.
item.content:encoded: The governor said he saw the recall's failure as a hopeful sign.

item.title: 5 takeaways from Newsom's big win in California's recall election

item.content:encoded: Here's what we know after the polls closed about the attempt to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom.

media:content.media:description: Governor Gavin Newsom speaks ahead of Vice President Kamala Harris at a rally against the upcoming California gubernatorial recall election at the IBEW-NECA Joint Apprenticeship Training Center on Wednesday, Sept. 8, 2021 in San Leandro. -- Republican gubernatorial candidate Larry Elder speaks at a news conference with firefighters on Thursday, Sept. 9, 2021 in Glendale.

item.title: It's now Larry Elder's California GOP. What's his next move?

item.description: Larry Elder shook up the recall campaign. What will the conservative talk radio host do next?
item.content:encoded: Larry Elder shook up the recall campaign. What will the conservative talk radio host do next?

item.title: California overwhelmingly rejects recall, keeps Newsom as governor
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Taryn Luna, Julia Wick
item.description: The election provided California voters an opportunity to judge Gov. Gavin Newsom's ability to lead the state through the COVID-19 pandemic, a worldwide health crisis that has shattered families and livelihoods.
item.content:encoded: The election provided California voters an opportunity to judge Gov. Gavin Newsom's ability to lead the state through the COVID-19 pandemic, a worldwide health crisis that has shattered families and livelihoods.

media:content.media:description: SAN LEANDRO, CA - SEPTEMBER 08: Governor Gavin Newsom speaks ahead of Vice President Kamala Harris at a rally against the upcoming California gubernatorial recall election at the IBEW-NECA Joint Apprenticeship Training Center on Wednesday, Sept. 8, 2021 in San Leandro, CA. The recall election, which will be held on September 14, 2021, asks voters to respond two questions: whether Newsom, a Democrat, should be recalled from the Office of Governor, and who would succeed Newsom should he be recalled. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: What to know as ballots are counted in the California recall election
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: The polls close at 8 p.m., and then the counting begins in California's recall election.
item.content:encoded: The polls close at 8 p.m., and then the counting begins in California's recall election.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 14: Robert Kalili who has already voted puts the "I VOTED" sticker on 19-month-old Chloe Kalili, held by her mother Sarah Kalili after the Westwood residents joined students, staff and nearby residents to cast their ballots at UCLA Ackerman Union as polls were open Tuesday for Californians to decide whether Gov. Gavin Newsom should be removed from office and, if so, who should replace him in a recall election. UCLA on Tuesday, Sept. 14, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times).

item.title: More than 9.5 million Californians have voted, a sign of hope for Newsom
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: Some 9.5 million Californians have returned ballots in the recall election, more than half them Democrats — a positive sign for Gov. Gavin Newsom as he tries to stay in office.
item.content:encoded: Some 9.5 million Californians have returned ballots in the recall election, more than half them Democrats — a positive sign for Gov. Gavin Newsom as he tries to stay in office.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CA - September 14, 2021: An election worker verifies signatures on mail-in ballots on the day of the Recall election at the Orange County Registrar in Santa Ana, California.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Earthquake: 3.0 quake shakes in San Fernando

item.title: In red California, recall backers fuel unfounded claims of 'rigged' voting, bait workers
item.dc:creator: Diana Marcum, Priscella Vega
item.description: The Central Valley has long been a stronghold for red California. And on Tuesday, there were loud voices of support for the recall while some election workers had to deal with taunts over unfounded conservative claims of election fraud.
item.content:encoded: The Central Valley has long been a stronghold for red California. And on Tuesday, there were loud voices of support for the recall while some election workers had to deal with taunts over unfounded conservative claims of election fraud.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 14: Students, staff and nearby residents cast their ballots at UCLA Ackerman Union as polls were open Tuesday for Californians to decide whether Gov. Gavin Newsom should be removed from office and, if so, who should replace him in a recall election. UCLA on Tuesday, Sept. 14, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times).

item.title: Newsom, Jenner address California recall election integrity as voters hit the polls
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust, Benjamin Oreskes, Faith E. Pinho, Melody Gutierrez
item.description: Newsom called out politicians and other figures he blames for peddling 'the Big Lie.' Some right-wing activists — as well as Elder — began sowing unfounded doubts about the integrity of the vote.
item.content:encoded: Newsom called out politicians and other figures he blames for peddling 'the Big Lie.' Some right-wing activists — as well as Elder — began sowing unfounded doubts about the integrity of the vote.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom, right, stands next to first partner Jennifer Siebel Newsom, and their daughter, Brooklynn, before speaking to volunteers in San Francisco, Tuesday, Sept. 14, 2021. The recall election that could remove California Democratic Gov. Newsom is coming to an end. Voting concludes Tuesday in the rare, late-summer election that has emerged as a national battlefront on issues from COVID-19 restrictions to climate change. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)

item.title: U.S. Forest Service to reopen all but 5 of California's national forests
item.dc:creator: Gregory Yee
item.description: The U.S. Forest Service announced Tuesday that all but five California national forests closed in late August will reopen two days early.
item.content:encoded: The U.S. Forest Service announced Tuesday that all but five California national forests closed in late August will reopen two days early.

Gavin Newsom should be removed from office and, if so, who should replace him in a recall election. UCLA on Tuesday, Sept. 14, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times).

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO, CA - MARCH 03, 2021 - Reese Bacon (R) waits in line to check in for his reservation to work out at a 24 Hour Fitness gym in San Francisco, California on March 03, 2021. As San Francisco moves into the red tier of the Covid-19 pandemic, gyms are now allowed to open at a maximum 10% capacity. (Josh Edelson/for the Times)

item.title: Photos: Newsom soundly defeats GOP-led recall effort

The recall election that could remove California Democratic Gov. Newsom is coming to an end. Voting concludes Tuesday in the rare, late-summer election that has emerged as a national battlefront on issues from COVID-19 restrictions to climate change. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)

item.title: Woman tethered to dog is dragged to death by BART train at San Francisco station
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II

item.title: KNP Complex fire threatening Sequoia National Park grows fivefold, forcing residents to flee

item.description: The Paradise and Colony fires have forced the evacuation of national park employees and residents of the Three Rivers community.
item.content:encoded: The Paradise and Colony fires have forced the evacuation of national park employees and residents of the Three Rivers community.

media:content.media:description: In this Sunday, Sept. 12, 2021 photo released by the KNP Complex Fire Incident Command, smoke plumes rise from the Paradise Fire in Sequoia National Park, Calif. In the southern Sierra Nevada, two fires ignited by lightning are burning in Sequoia National Park. (KNP Complex Fire Incident Command via AP)
media:content.media:credit: Riley Hays / KNP Complex Fire Incident Command

item.title: California judicial watchdog admonishes L.A. judge for biased social media posts

item.content:encoded: A judicial watchdog commission publicly admonished an Los Angeles Superior Court judge for showing bias on Facebook and Twitter.

Facebook says the U.S. Department of Homeland Security will be violating the company's rules if agents create fake profiles to monitor the social media of foreigners seeking to enter the country. (AP Photo/Jenny Kane, File)

item.title: L.A. City Council tightens law around protests outside private homes

item.description: The L.A. City Council voted to limit protests outside residences, passing a law that lets targets and others seek fines from unlawful demonstrators.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. City Council voted to limit protests outside residences, passing a law that lets targets and others seek fines from unlawful demonstrators.

(Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: A woman was skateboarding on Tampa Avenue south of Oxnard Street around 12:30 a.m. when she was struck by a silver four-door sedan.

media:content.media:description: An investigation is underway after a woman, who was skateboarding, was killed in a hit-and-run collision in Tarzana early Tuesday morning.

item.title: California coronavirus cases dropping, CDC says
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money
item.description: California's coronavirus transmission level has fallen from 'high' to 'substantial,' the second-highest tier as defined by the CDC.
item.content:encoded: California's coronavirus transmission level has fallen from 'high' to 'substantial,' the second-highest tier as defined by the CDC.

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's map of coronavirus community transmission levels Tuesday evening shows California as the only state to fall out of the worst category of coronavirus transmission.
media:content.media:credit: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Riverside County sheriff says he will not enforce COVID-19 vaccine mandates
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: According to Sheriff Chad Bianco, "The government has no ability and no authority to mandate your health choices."
item.content:encoded: According to Sheriff Chad Bianco, "The government has no ability and no authority to mandate your health choices."

media:content.media:description: Chad Bianco was elected Sheriff, Coroner, and Public Administrator of Riverside County in the November 6, 2018, general election. He is a twenty-five-year veteran of the Riverside County Sheriff's Department. As Sheriff, he will serve as the Chief Law Enforcement Officer of Riverside County.

item.title: L.A. Metro offers free bus, train and bike rides to recall election voting centers
item.dc:creator: Melissa Hernandez
item.description: Voting centers across California will be open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Tuesday for those looking to cast in-person ballots in the recall election.
item.content:encoded: Voting centers across California will be open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Tuesday for those looking to cast in-person ballots in the recall election.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- THURSDAY, MARCH 26, 2020: A man sits in a nearly empty train car on the Metro Blue Line at 7th St/Metro Center station in Los Angeles, Calif., on March 26, 2020. The coronavirus pandemic is causing ridership on LA Metro trains and busses to plummet. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: California at a crossroads as recall voters decide fate of Newsom, future of state
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo, Andrew J. Campa, Benjamin Oreskes, Ruben Vives, Susanne Rust, Luke Money
item.description: The closely watched recall campaign carries immense consequences, not just for the nation's most populous state, but for the nation as a whole.
item.content:encoded: The closely watched recall campaign carries immense consequences, not just for the nation's most populous state, but for the nation as a whole.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 13: Josh Hodas, left, and partner Serena Delgadillo, right, are among people casting their votes Monday morning in the historic Los Angeles Union Station Ticket Hall or Main Concourse built in 1939 as the largest railroad passenger terminal in the Western United States. The Union Station Hall is serving as a Vote Center for the recall effort against California Governor Gavin Newsom. Union Station on Monday, Sept. 13, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times).

item.title: Examining the conspiracy theories, legal threats and Trump fraud claims in the California recall
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: Weeks before Californians went to the polls, some right-wing activists — as well as leading GOP candidate Larry Elder — began sowing doubts about the integrity of the vote.
item.content:encoded: Weeks before Californians went to the polls, some right-wing activists — as well as leading GOP candidate Larry Elder — began sowing doubts about the integrity of the vote.

media:content.media:description: Santa Ana, CA - September 09: Observers (who declined to give their names) from the Election Integrity Project watch ballots be processed (and signatures verified) at vote centers across the state during the California Gubernatorial Recall Election, including the Orange County Registrar of Voters in Santa Ana Thursday, Sept. 9, 2021. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Jury begins deliberations in Robert Durst murder trial
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A jury begins deliberating whether to convict Robert Durst of murdering his best friend, who allegedly helped cover up Durst's killing of his wife.
item.content:encoded: A jury begins deliberating whether to convict Robert Durst of murdering his best friend, who allegedly helped cover up Durst's killing of his wife.

media:content.media:description: INGLEWOOD, CA - SEPTEMBER 08: Robert Durst looks at jurors as he appears in an Inglewood courtroom with his attorneys for the first closing arguments presented by the prosecution in the murder trial of the New York real estate scion who is charged with the longtime friend Susan Bermans killing in Benedict Canyon just before Christmas Eve 2000. Inglewood Courthouse on Wednesday, Sept. 8, 2021 in Inglewood, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times).

item.title: Column: Win or lose, Larry Elder could bring about a new era of Black conservatism
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: Black Republicans are rare in California, but they hope the bombastic recall candidate will inspire more people of color to run for elected office.
item.content:encoded: Black Republicans are rare in California, but they hope the bombastic recall candidate will inspire more people of color to run for elected office.

media:content.media:description: DOWNEY, CA - SEPTEMBER 09, 2021: Gubernatorial candidate Larry Elder gestures to the audience while participating in a town hall meeting at New Season LA/Downey Church in Downey. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California fires are burning at higher elevations than ever, creating new dangers
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Climate warming has exposed an additional 31,400 square miles of forests to fire at higher elevations, where flames are scorching terrains that previously were too wet to burn.
item.content:encoded: Climate warming has exposed an additional 31,400 square miles of forests to fire at higher elevations, where flames are scorching terrains that previously were too wet to burn.

media:content.media:description: JANESVILLE, CALIF. - AUG. 18, 2021. The setting sun is obscured by burned trees and a pall of smoke from the Dixie Fire near Janesville, Calif., on Friday, Aug. 20, 2021. The wildfire has burned more than 1,100 square miles, destroyed 659 homes and is only about 30 percent contained. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newsom recall election tests the California dream
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: The gubernatorial recall election demonstrates a truth about modern California: We have lost patience amid many crises, and any proposal that doesn't lead to a fix is reason to mobilize.
item.content:encoded: The gubernatorial recall election demonstrates a truth about modern California: We have lost patience amid many crises, and any proposal that doesn't lead to a fix is reason to mobilize.

media:content.media:description: A supporter gestures the victory sign as Republican gubernatorial candidate Larry Elder speaks to supporters during an Asian Rally for Yes Recall at the Asian Garden Mall in Little Saigon, Westminster, California, on September 4, 2021. - The recall election, which will be held on September 14, 2021, asks voters to respond two questions: whether Newsom, a Democratic, should be recalled from the office of governor, and who should succeed Newsom if he is recalled. Forty-six candidates, including nine Democrats and 24 Republicans, are looking to take Newsom's place as the governmental leader of California. (Photo by RINGO CHIU / AFP) (Photo by RINGO CHIU/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Earthquake: Magnitude 3.8 quake hits near Coalinga
item.dc:creator: Quakebot

item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.8 earthquake is reported early Tuesday 14 miles from Coalinga, according to the USGS.

item.title: Thousands of LAPD employees plan to seek exemptions to COVID-19 vaccine mandate
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Kevin Rector
item.description: More than 2,600 LAPD employees have indicated that they plan to pursue religious exemptions, while more than 350 plan to seek medical ones, according to a source in city government.
item.content:encoded: More than 2,600 LAPD employees have indicated that they plan to pursue religious exemptions, while more than 350 plan to seek medical ones, according to a source in city government.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 14, 2021 - - Los Angeles police officers keep an eye out after advocates against vaccine mandates and pro-vaccine advocates confronted each other in front of the L.A.P.D. Headquarters in downtown Los Angeles on August 14, 2021. A man was stabbed during the melee and taken by paramedics to a nearby hospital. No arrests were made in the confrontation. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD badly miscalculated weight of fireworks before South L.A. explosion, ATF finds
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia, Kevin Rector
item.description: LAPD Chief Michel Moore said the fireworks placed in the containment vessel were not weighed with a scale, but eyeballed by technicians.
item.content:encoded: LAPD Chief Michel Moore said the fireworks placed in the containment vessel were not weighed with a scale, but eyeballed by technicians.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - July 04: Investigation continues in a fireworks explosion that destroyed a LAPD's bomb squad vehicle last Wednesday at 700 block of East 27th Street on Sunday, July 4, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

The Santa Clara County registrar of voters is preparing to take in and process thousands of ballots in the recall election of Gov. Gavin Newsom as early voting is underway in the state of California. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

item.content:encoded: President Biden visited a firefighting headquarters in Idaho before he's expected to tour wildfire damage near Sacramento.

Gavin Newsom the night before the recall election in Long Beach, California.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

(Wally Skalij / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Can California avoid another COVID-19 surge? Britain offers a sober warning
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money
item.description: California's overall pandemic trends appear to be improving, but that course has been upended before.
item.content:encoded: California's overall pandemic trends appear to be improving, but that course has been upended before.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - SEPTEMBER 08: Respiratory Therapist Kaylee Knight works with a covid19 positive patient inside the ICU Ventura County Medical Center - a hospital in the city of Ventura, on Wednesday, Sept. 8, 2021 in Ventura, CA. Today the hospital reports they have 22 covid19 posstive patients plus 3 under investigation. Of those cases, 4 are reported vaccinated and 2 are partially vaccinated and 16 are unvaccinated. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Stumping for Larry Elder, Rose McGowan drums up recall drama by bashing Newsom family
item.dc:creator: Nardine Saad
item.description: Actor-activist Rose McGowan appeared Sunday with Republican candidate Larry Elder to denounce California Gov. Gavin Newsom's wife and family.
item.content:encoded: Actor-activist Rose McGowan appeared Sunday with Republican candidate Larry Elder to denounce California Gov. Gavin Newsom's wife and family.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 12: Candidate for governor Larry Elder, left, and Rose McGowan, actress, multimedia artist, writer, right, speak during a press confrence at the Luxe Hotel Sunset Boulevard on Sunday, Sept. 12, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. Rose McGowan and Larry Elder hold a press conference to discuss her allegations against Jennifer Siebel Newsom, Governor Gavin Newsom's wife. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Retiring its racist name, historic Squaw Valley resort will become Palisades Tahoe
item.dc:creator: Hugo Martín
item.description: The Lake Tahoe-area ski resort Squaw Valley is adopting a new name after weighing criticisms that 'squaw' is a sexist slur against Indigenous women.
item.content:encoded: The Lake Tahoe-area ski resort Squaw Valley is adopting a new name after weighing criticisms that 'squaw' is a sexist slur against Indigenous women.

media:content.media:description: The Olympic rings stand atop a sign at the entrance to the Squaw Valley Ski Resort in Olympic Valley, Calif., July 8, 2020. California's Squaw Valley Ski Resort is considering changing its name to remove "squaw," a derogatory term for Native American women. Squaw Valley President & CEO Ron Cohen says resort officials are meeting with shareholders and the local Washoe tribal leadership to get their input. He says he can't give a timeline on when the decision will be made. The renaming of Squaw Valley Ski Resort is one of many efforts across the nation to address colonialism and indigenous oppression. (AP Photo/Haven Daley)

item.title: California recall voting: Conspiracy theories, unproven fraud claims, and the facts you need
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: The campaigning is all but over. As surveys show the recall effort struggling, some Republicans have made unproven claims of fraud.
item.content:encoded: The campaigning is all but over. As surveys show the recall effort struggling, some Republicans have made unproven claims of fraud.

media:content.media:description: Santa Ana, CA - September 09: An observer who declined to give their name, watches election workers process ballots (and signatures verified) at vote centers across the state during the California Gubernatorial Recall Election, including the Orange County Registrar of Voters in Santa Ana Thursday, Sept. 9, 2021. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Mother killed while holding 3-year-old son in Playa del Rey hit-and-run
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: The 33-year-old mother of two was carrying her son when she was struck by a car on Vista Del Mar near Dockweiler State Beach.
item.content:encoded: The 33-year-old mother of two was carrying her son when she was struck by a car on Vista Del Mar near Dockweiler State Beach.

item.title: Earthquake: Magnitude 3.6 quake rattles Thousand Oaks
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.6 earthquake was recorded at 7:59 a.m. in Thousand Oaks, according to the USGS.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.6 earthquake was recorded at 7:59 a.m. in Thousand Oaks, according to the USGS.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 3.6 earthquake was recorded Monday morning Sept. 13, 2021, in Thousand Oaks, Calif.

item.title: Column: Larry Elder and the danger of the 'model minority' candidate
item.dc:creator: Frank Shyong
item.description: Larry Elder is an example of a model minority candidate, a politician who succeeds by betraying their community. Think of it as first stepping on the people around you so you can appear to be pulling yourself up by the bootstraps.
item.content:encoded: Larry Elder is an example of a model minority candidate, a politician who succeeds by betraying their community. Think of it as first stepping on the people around you so you can appear to be pulling yourself up by the bootstraps.

media:content.media:description: CASTAIC, CA - SEPTEMBER 06, 2021: Gubernatorial candidate Larry Elder addresses the crowd during a rally at Freedom's Way Baptist Church in Castaic. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Who will follow L.A. school district in mandating vaccines for students?
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Melissa Gomez
item.description: With a mandate for students to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, L.A. Unified puts itself out there for emulation, adulation, scorn and litigation.
item.content:encoded: With a mandate for students to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, L.A. Unified puts itself out there for emulation, adulation, scorn and litigation.

media:content.media:description: SAN FERNANDO, CA - AUGUST 30, 2021:Katherine Baltazar,12, a 7th grader at San Fernando Middle School in San Fernando, receives the first dose of the Pfiizer vaccine from Lynn-Ti Allen, a licensed vocational nurse. A mobile COVID-19 vaccine clinic was set up inside the gymnasium at San Fernando Middle School to inoculate LAUSD employees and students age 12 and older. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Larry Elder joining the recall race was the best thing that could've happened to Newsom
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Elder carried with him three decades of provocative right-wing rhetoric that Newsom turned into a scary wake-up alarm for snoozing Democrats, columnist George Skelton writes.
item.content:encoded: Elder carried with him three decades of provocative right-wing rhetoric that Newsom turned into a scary wake-up alarm for snoozing Democrats, columnist George Skelton writes.

media:content.media:description: SUN VALLEY, CA - SEPTEMBER 12: Gov. Gavin Newsom greets the crowd following his campaign rally in Sun Valley urging those gathered to vote no on the recall. Photographed at Chef Robert Catering on Sunday, Sept. 12, 2021 in Sun Valley, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Sirhan Sirhan's possible parole creates divide in Kennedy family and beyond
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Sirhan Sirhan's parole recommendation has spurred debate over whether people who have committed horrific crimes should be allowed to rejoin society.
item.content:encoded: Sirhan Sirhan's parole recommendation has spurred debate over whether people who have committed horrific crimes should be allowed to rejoin society.

media:content.media:description: Sirhan Sirhan is sworn in during a parole hearing Wednesday, Feb. 10, 2016, at the Richard J. Donovan Correctional Facility in San Diego. For the 15th time, officials denied parole for Sirhan Sirhan, the assassin of Sen. Robert F. Kennedy, after hearing Wednesday from another person who was shot that night and called for the release of Sirhan. (AP Photo/Gregory Bull, Pool)

item.title: As fires burn and crises bubble, a tiny theater in a speck of a California town rekindles joy
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: The COVID-19 pandemic, then the Caldor fire and smoke, closed the theater in rural Volcano, Calif., for more than 18 months. But the show must go on.
item.content:encoded: The COVID-19 pandemic, then the Caldor fire and smoke, closed the theater in rural Volcano, Calif., for more than 18 months. But the show must go on.

media:content.media:description: VOLCANO, CA - SEPTEMBER 03: The Volcano Theatre Company performed Noel Coward's "Hay Fever" to a nearly packed amphitheatre on Friday, Sept. 3, 2021 after more than a year of closures and reopenings because of COVD-19 and the recent fire and smoke. The attendance was about 100 nearly filling the amphitheater to capacity. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: COVID-19 got this medical team into homeless camps. What about after the pandemic?
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: COVID-19 marked the beginning of street medicine teams from L.A. County health services visiting homeless encampments. The agency hopes it won't be the end.
item.content:encoded: COVID-19 marked the beginning of street medicine teams from L.A. County health services visiting homeless encampments. The agency hopes it won't be the end.

media:content.media:description: SANTA FE SPRINGS, CA - AUGUST 18: Dr. Absalon Galat, left, County of Los Angeles Department of Health Services Ambulatory Care Network uses a portable ultrasound connected to his iPhone to examine Luz Juarez, 58, right, who is living next to the La Canada Verde Creek on Wednesday, Aug. 18, 2021 in Santa Fe Springs, CA. Dr. Galat is examining Luz Juarez, whose arm and hand were still swollen from an abscess that had stubbornly resisted the antibiotics they had already provided. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: News Analysis: As recall campaign closes, Californians might be ready to change the system
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: Academics and activists alike say that improvements to the rules and reasons for a recall contest are long overdue. And polling indicates voters might be ready for changes too.
item.content:encoded: Academics and activists alike say that improvements to the rules and reasons for a recall contest are long overdue. And polling indicates voters might be ready for changes too.

media:content.media:description: SUN VALLEY, CA - SEPTEMBER 12: Gov. Gavin Newsom takes a picture with Joseph Martinez, left, and Christopher Gray following his campaign rally in Sun Valley urging those gathered to vote no on the recall. Photographed at Chef Robert Catering on Sunday, Sept. 12, 2021 in Sun Valley, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newsom slams GOP, while Elder targets governor's wife as recall campaign closes
item.dc:creator: Faith E. Pinho, James Rainey
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom and Republican front-runner Larry Elder fanned out across L.A. on Sunday to make their final push to voters in California's recall election.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom and Republican front-runner Larry Elder fanned out across L.A. on Sunday to make their final push to voters in California's recall election.

media:content.media:description: SUN VALLEY, CA - SEPTEMBER 12: Gov. Gavin Newsom takes a picture with Joseph Martinez, left, and Christopher Gray following his campaign rally in Sun Valley urging those gathered to vote no on the recall. Photographed at Chef Robert Catering on Sunday, Sept. 12, 2021 in Sun Valley, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD employees sue city over vaccination mandate
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: A group of Los Angeles Police Department employees has filed a federal lawsuit challenging the city's mandate that all L.A. employees be vaccinated against COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: A group of Los Angeles Police Department employees has filed a federal lawsuit challenging the city's mandate that all L.A. employees be vaccinated against COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 14, 2021 - - Los Angeles police officers go to separate advocates against vaccine mandates and pro-vaccine advocates in front of the L.A.P.D. Headquarters in downtown Los Angeles on August 14, 2021. A man was stabbed during the melee and taken by paramedics to a nearby hospital. No arrests were made in the confrontation. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Inland Empire parents of 5 die of COVID-19 weeks apart
item.dc:creator: Kim Christensen
item.description: The couple and their four children all contracted the coronavirus after a trip to Big Sur in July, which included a stop on the way back at an indoor water park in Orange County.
item.content:encoded: The couple and their four children all contracted the coronavirus after a trip to Big Sur in July, which included a stop on the way back at an indoor water park in Orange County.

media:content.media:description: An Inland Empire family is mourning the loss of two parents who died of COVID-19 just weeks apart, leaving behind five children, family members said Friday. Daniel Macias, a 39-year-old middle school teacher, was diagnosed with COVID-19 soon after his wife, Davy Macias, a 37-year-old San Bernardino County nurse who had recently given birth to their fifth child before dying from COVID-19 late last month. The couple leaves behind their newborn daughter and four other children, ages 7, 5, 3 and 2. The children are being cared for by their grandparents, family members said.

item.title: Structures burn as fire sweeps into Mendocino County community, north of Santa Rosa
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: The Hopkins fire has burned about 300 acres and is 0% contained.
item.content:encoded: The Hopkins fire has burned about 300 acres and is 0% contained.

item.title: Firefighters get help from weather in battling Northern California blazes
item.dc:creator: Kim Christensen
item.description: Caldor and Dixie wildfires both are 65% contained as of Sunday morning.
item.content:encoded: Caldor and Dixie wildfires both are 65% contained as of Sunday morning.

media:content.media:description: GREENVILLE, CA - AUGUST 08, 2021: Horses graze in a field off of North Valley Road in Greenville as the Dixie Fire continues to burn near the town. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)
